title: If a random variable 'X' follows Poisson Distribution such that P(X=1) = P(X=2), then what is P(X=0)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for A2A, Ananya Chatterjee If a random variable 'X' follows Poisson Distribution such that P(X=1) = P(X=2), then what is P(X=0)? Given, [math]“X”[/math] follows Poisson distribution. We know that the density function of Poisson distribution is[math] ~\boxed{\frac{e^{-\lambda}\left(\lambda \right)^{x}}{x!}}[/math] Here, [math]“X”[/math] is random variable and [math]\lambda[/math] is the parameter of distribution. Remember: Parameter of a distribution defines the character of the population. So, if we got the value of parameter, we can find the probability for any value of random variable [math]“X”[/math] that it assumes[math] ~“(x)"[/math]. [math]P(X = 1) ~= ~P(X=2)[/math] [math]\implies~\frac{e^{-\lambda}\left(\lambda \right)^{1}}{1!}~=~\frac{e^{-\lambda}\left(\lambda \right)^{2}}{2!}[/math] [math]\implies~2e^{-\lambda}{\lambda}~=~ e^{-\lambda}{\lambda^{2}}[/math] [math]\implies~2 ~ \lambda ~=~ \lambda^{2}[/math] [math]\implies~\huge{\huge{\boxed{\lambda~=~2}}}[/math] Thus, we just need to put the value of parameter in the required probability. [math]P(X=0)~=~\frac{e^{-\lambda}\left(\lambda \right)^{0}}{0!}[/math] [math]\implies~\huge{\boxed{\boxed{P(X=0)~=~e^{-2}~=~0.1353}}}[/math] That's it, In the case we haven't met before, I'm Krishna Singh Thanks! [math]~\huge{\huge{\boxed{\boxed{\ddot{\smallsmile}}}}}[/math]

Since it is Poisson distributed Random variable P(X=k)=[λ^k.e^(-λ)]/k! Given, P(X=1) we get P(X=1)=[λ.e^(-λ)]/(1!) P(X=1)=λe^(-λ)….(1) P(X=2)=[λ².e^(-λ)]/2! P(X=2)=[λ².e^(-λ)]/2….(2) Given equation (1) and (2) P(X=1)=P(X=2) λ.e^(-λ) = [λ².(e^(-λ)]/2 2λe^(-λ)=λ²e^(-λ) Since e^(±x) is always greater than zero we can cancel it on both the sides, we get 2λ=λ² λ²-2λ=0 λ(λ-2)=0 λ=0 οr λ=2 But λ cannot be zero as it is a mean, hence λ=2 We require to find the probability at X=0 so, P(X=k)=(λ^ke^(-λ))/k! At X=0 the probability is derived by putting k=0 So, P(X=0)=(λ^(0).e^(-λ))/0! P(X=0)=(1.e^(-λ))/1 P(X=0)=e^(-λ) But λ=2, so, P(X=0)=e-² P(X=0)=1/e² P(X=0)=0.135335283236

For a poisson variate X with parameter m, P(X = r) = exp(-m) m^r/r! ; r = 0, 1, 2, 3, …. …. ; it is given that P(X = 1) = P(X = 2) ==> exp(-m) m^1/ 1! = exp(-m) m^2/2! ==> m^2 - 2m = 0 ==> m = 2 (as m is not zero) . Hence ; P(X = 0) = exp(-m) m^0/0! = exp(-2) .
So ,as we know Poisson distribution is P(X)= e^-l*l^x/X! As P(X=1)=P(X=2), so l=2 as l>0 Now P(X=0)= e^-2/0!=1/e^2
